Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2009 08:36PM AngelaD wrote: Lisa - Hello from Lynden Washington!  My diagnosis was very similar to yours, but I was BRCA1 Pos.  My treatments have been and will always be in Seattle & my outcome has been great so far!  I will be thinking of you often and hoping all goes well with your surgery & new marriage!   I've been where you are and remember the difficult time between the initial identification of the cancer to the "crappy gene discovery" and finally the date for the initial BLM, BSO and TE's on 10/13.  I think that is one of the most difficult times in the entire process.  Trying to sort out the diagnosis and the path to surgery can make you pull out all of your hair and that a few other people's too! I wish you the very best and will be thinking about you on the 10th!  Feel free to PM with questions or for support!  Angie - from the land of windmills and mowed lawns!
Posts.Title: February Surgery jillisucat 2new1s

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2009 04:25AM AngelaD wrote: Hi Nancy -  I am 3 months out from a BLM with TE and haven't worn a Bra or any other undergarment more than 12 times.  I usually layer a front zipp sweatshirt or button-up blouse over a stretch nylon tight t-shirt (like v-neck under armour)  It gives me the coverage over my mastectomy scars which are about 2 inches across where my nipple/areola used to be, and it gives me the option of zipping the sweatshirt up/down for coolness.   I found anything that gathered underneath my breasts to be irritating and bothersome.  Once in a while I wear a lightly padded spandex camisole (victoria secret) when I want to wear a tighter fitting or thinner top. This has been the routine since my BLM and initial expander fill to 200cc.  I am now 480 cc on the right and 500 on the left. Will exchange on 2/4 and doc says I probably wont need a bra after that !!!!  Hope that helps.
Posts.Title: When Can I get My life Back? NancyNJ nobleanna007

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2009 12:41PM AngelaD wrote: Hi Michelle -  I had my BLM, SNB, TE, OOPH & BL HYS all on October 13, 2008.  I'm very glad I had everything done together.  The surgery went great, 9 hours in all, and I hardly noticed the laproscopic ooph, and hysterectomy.   I am an active 42 year old, non-smoker/drinker and in above average shape.  I'm not sure how it impacts everyone else.  The worst part was the 3 weeks of resting and not moving arms above 45 degrees that drove me crazy!  All in all, the recovery was more boring than painful.  Make sure you have something for the gas.  I should've taken something to cut down on the abdominal post-surgery gas.  I was home from the hospital in 2.5 days, and off the narcotics in about 5 days. Have had exchange now and nipples are almost done.  All is well.  Best of luck with your surgery.  AngelaD
Posts.Title: Breast and Ovary Surgery at the Same Time strngwmn39 Silverpullet

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2009 11:07PM AngelaD wrote: Cornstarch baby powder worked for me - It lifted the residue off when I rubbed the spot with my fingers.  Worked way better than anything else I tried. Hope this helps!
Posts.Title: How do you remove adhesive residue from the skin? MaryNY toto2

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2008 06:31PM AngelaD wrote: Hello Dannielle -  My heart goes out to you - at the same time, I would agree with the wise advice above - take your time, talk to a wide variety of surgeons, genetic counselors, and family to help guide your decision making.  Most of all, take charge of your health care and your path through this experience.  Another site that you might find of value is the following http://www.youngsurvival.org/community/bulletin-board/ I found the more research I read and the more I knew about the procedures, percentages and survival rates helped me make the final decisions about my treatment.  Also knowing how you want to live the rest of your life is important and factors into the quality of life questions you face in the decision making process.   The process of deciding how to handle the diagnosis was the most challenging and difficult for me emotionally.  The weeks and months of learning, evaluating and deciding meant looking deep into my heart and mind to make difficult decisions.  There is much light at the end of the tunnel as long as your decision is one that you believe in.  Guide your treatment and follow your gut-feeling about your doctors, diagnosis and plan.    All the best to you in this journey - one step at a time.
